content.body: Howdy all, can someone help me understand what 'toString' is? Is it a function object? I don't get it at all.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Howdy all, can someone help me understand what 'toString' is? Is it a function object? I don't get it at all.

content.body: There are built-in functions named 'toString', yes.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: There are built-in functions named 'toString', yes.

content.body: e.g. Object.prototype.toString, Boolean.prototype.toString
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: e.g. Object.prototype.toString, Boolean.prototype.toString

content.body: Within the spec, there's also `ToString` (note the capital `T`) which is something different.
content.formatted_body: Within the spec, there's also ToString (note the capital T) which is something different.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Within the spec, there's also `ToString` (note the capital `T`) which is something different.
Within the spec, there's also ToString (note the capital T) which is something different.

content.body: So this is the part of the specification that pertains to it? https://262.ecma-international.org/12.0/#sec-built-in-function-objects
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: So this is the part of the specification that pertains to it? https://262.ecma-international.org/12.0/#sec-built-in-function-objects

content.body: Thank you for the help btw
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Thank you for the help btw

content.body: Yup, that section does pertain to the built-in `toString` functions, but it's not the *only* pertinent section.
content.formatted_body: Yup, that section does pertain to the built-in toString functions, but it's not the only pertinent section.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Yup, that section does pertain to the built-in `toString` functions, but it's not the *only* pertinent section.
Yup, that section does pertain to the built-in toString functions, but it's not the only pertinent section.

content.body: Each built-in `toString` function has its own section in the spec.
content.formatted_body: Each built-in toString function has its own section in the spec.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Each built-in `toString` function has its own section in the spec.
Each built-in toString function has its own section in the spec.

content.body: e.g. Object.prototype.toString is defined here: https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-object.prototype.tostring
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: e.g. Object.prototype.toString is defined here: https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-object.prototype.tostring

content.body: Okay, got it. So there's one for each primitive type?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Okay, got it. So there's one for each primitive type?

content.body: That makes sense.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: That makes sense.

content.body: I have another tangential question.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I have another tangential question.

content.body: The expression statement "toString.constructor" is the function constructor for the "toString" method. This is the section related to it, right? https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-function-constructor
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: The expression statement "toString.constructor" is the function constructor for the "toString" method. This is the section related to it, right? https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-function-constructor

content.body: TLDR, I'm trying to understand how ECMAScript evalutaes the statement "toString.constructor.prototype".
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: TLDR, I'm trying to understand how ECMAScript evalutaes the statement "toString.constructor.prototype".

content.body: Hm...

content.body: None of the built-in `toString` functions has a property named `constructor`, so I wouldn't expect `toString.constructor` to mean anything.
content.formatted_body: None of the built-in toString functions has a property named constructor, so I wouldn't expect toString.constructor to mean anything.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: None of the built-in `toString` functions has a property named `constructor`, so I wouldn't expect `toString.constructor` to mean anything.
None of the built-in toString functions has a property named constructor, so I wouldn't expect toString.constructor to mean anything.

content.body: They don't have an *own* property by that name,
content.formatted_body: They don't have an own property by that name,

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: They don't have an *own* property by that name,
They don't have an own property by that name,

content.body: but they all have Function.prototype as their `[[Prototype]]`
content.formatted_body: but they all have Function.prototype as their [[Prototype]]

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: but they all have Function.prototype as their `[[Prototype]]`
but they all have Function.prototype as their [[Prototype]]

content.body: So it's accessed by the prototype chain, got it
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: So it's accessed by the prototype chain, got it

content.body: Yup, Function.prototype has a property named `constructor`, whose value is (initially at least) the `Function` object.
content.formatted_body: Yup, Function.prototype has a property named constructor, whose value is (initially at least) the Function object.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Yup, Function.prototype has a property named `constructor`, whose value is (initially at least) the `Function` object.
Yup, Function.prototype has a property named constructor, whose value is (initially at least) the Function object.

content.body: So initially, `toString.constructor.prototype` would refer to the `Function.prototype` object.
content.formatted_body: So initially, toString.constructor.prototype would refer to the Function.prototype object.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: So initially, `toString.constructor.prototype` would refer to the `Function.prototype` object.
So initially, toString.constructor.prototype would refer to the Function.prototype object.

content.body: I think I got that right.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I think I got that right.

content.body:
Okay. So to summarize:

The built-in function =toString= links to the function object Function via the prototype chain.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text:
Okay. So to summarize:

The built-in function =toString= links to the function object Function via the prototype chain.

content.body: r3st: sounds like you're trying to understand how somehow is reaching into `Function.prototype`, probably related to some prototype pollution ?

content.body: there are a million ways to get to intrinsics prototypes. Best defense is usually to check for own properties before drilling into a parsed value.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: there are a million ways to get to intrinsics prototypes. Best defense is usually to check for own properties before drilling into a parsed value.

content.body: and to use define prop instead of doing an assignment when the there is no own prop
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: and to use define prop instead of doing an assignment when the there is no own prop

content.body: a ton of query string parsers do this wrong
